Award.AwardTitle: The Assembly of Photosynthetic Light-Harvesting Complexes in Whole Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary project will bring together sophisticated biological and structural monitoring of photosynthetic membrane assembly, function and regulation with the tools of dynamic spectroscopy required to record and analyze the detailed function of the in vivo system. There are three parts to the project. First, an analysis of individual components of the photosynthetic apparatus in cells (the light harvesting complexes and the reaction center) coupled with an analysis of their action together under well defined conditions will allow the generation of a quantitative structure/function model. Next, by varying light regimes, it is possible to change the relative amounts and presumably the organization of the different components, making it possible to refine the model so that it takes into account the range of different architectures that the apparatus can assume. Finally, the higher order structure and function of the photosynthetic apparatus will be monitored as a function of its development, starting from aerobic conditions where it is largely absent and removing oxygen which initiates the production and assembly of the components. An understanding of membrane system assembly in this model system will aid the much broader field of membrane structure/function relationships. This system is likely unique in the fact that the components are well characterized structurally and functionally, the genetic system is facile, and the tools exist now to follow the function of the unmodified membrane system in living cells.

This project is being supported jointly by the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Physics Division and by Biomolecular Dynamics, Structure and Function in MCB.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes. The assembly of membrane proteins into complexes and higher order structures plays a critical role in defining the function and regulation of biological processes.  However, relatively little is known at a mechanistic level about this area of biology, largely because of the difficulty involved in both determining the organization of components in membrane systems and in following the functions of individual components and the interactions between them.

A multi-parameter approach was used to maximize the information and minimize signal mixing from complexed biological systems in whole cells. There are two major advantages in using the photosynthetic membranes of purple nonsulfur bacteria as a model system for probing structure-function relationships in complex membrane systems. One is the ability to manipulate the native structure of the photosynthetic apparatus in these organisms via growth conditions, allowing the expression of membrane components in different stoichiometries and architectures. Another is to use the native optical reporter groups embedded in membranes to simultaneously follow the dynamics of energy and electron transfer and to associate their spectral changes with dynamics by optical spectroscopic methods. Thus, individual components and the interactions between components can be monitored without perturbing the system. The light harvesting complexes 1 and 2 (LH1 and LH2), and reaction center protein (RC), have their characteristic spectral signatures and energy transfer rate constants. The time-dependent spectral change, coupled with structural data from AFM, allow detailed kinetic modeling that connects particular architectures to the function and efficiency of the light-harvesting network at the cellular level.

We have systematically measured the LH2 and LH1 fluorescence kinetics from whole cells, chromatophores isolated from the intracytoplasmic membrane (ICM, invaginated portions of the membrane), and the nascent ICM growth initiation sites (partially invaginated domains of the cytoplasmic membrane isolated as an upper pigmented band, UPB) starting with cells that were harvested at different developmental stages after shifting from high- to low-light growth conditions.  The high to low light transition is known to generate a major remodeling in the structure and composition of the photosynthetic apparatus in these organisms. Results from fluorescence kinetic studies have been used in kinetic modeling, which has revealed different functions of two pools of LH2 antenna in cells growing under low light conditions. The LH2 pool localized between rows of LH1-RC dimers apparently transfers excitation energy to LH1-RC efficiently, while LH2 in LH2-only regions is functionally loosely coupled to or disconnected from the LH1-RC array. This conclusion is in line with AFM observations of two structurally distinct pools of LH2 formed under low-light conditions.  An illustration of these concepts is shown in the figure. Moreover, the ability to distinguish the energy transfer kinetics of LH1 and LH2 has allowed us to monitor the assembly processes of the photosynthetic apparatus in ICM vesicles and the UPB as a function of time after the shift in lighting conditions.
